title: 111_hr2991
content:
The Act titled "Department of Transportation Bonding Assistance Authority Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss from a principal's breach of bond. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss resulting from a breach of bid, payment, or performance bonds by an eligible small business concern bidding on a contract. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss from avoiding breach for eligible small businesses bidding on contracts. The small business must meet specific criteria to qualify for the bond guarantee. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against loss in avoiding a breach of a guaranteed bond, with certain conditions such as approval prior to payment and a limit of 10 percent of the contract price. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against loss in avoiding a breach of a guaranteed bond, with conditions including prior approval for payments and a maximum payment of 10 percent of the contract price. The Secretary may reimburse the surety for up to 90 percent of the loss incurred and paid by the surety. The Secretary may reimburse the surety for up to 90 percent of the loss incurred and paid by the surety, with conditions and exceptions outlined. The Secretary may reimburse the surety for up to 90 percent of the loss incurred and paid by the surety, with conditions and exceptions outlined. The surety shall be relieved of liability if obtained guarantee by fraud, breached terms, or violated regulations. The Secretary may establish regulations for participating sureties regarding underwriting, claim practices, and reimbursement procedures. The Secretary may adopt a procedure for reimbursing a surety for paid losses, with monthly adjustments based on prior payments. Participating sureties must report to the Secretary and be audited at least once every three years. The Secretary administers the subsection by auditing participating sureties every three years and establishing fees for small businesses and premiums for sureties. A state program may be established for selected states to carry out specific activities under this subsection. The Secretary may establish a state program for selected states to carry out activities related to issuing guarantees and assisting small businesses. Selected states must meet prescribed standards and submit annual reports to the Secretary. The Secretary may establish a state program for selected states to issue guarantees and assist small businesses. States must meet prescribed standards and submit annual reports to the Secretary, detailing the program's nature, total guarantees provided, and the number of participating small businesses. Additionally, the Secretary must submit an annual report to specific committees, outlining the implementation of the program and the number of sureties receiving guarantees. The Secretary may establish a state program for selected states to issue guarantees and assist small businesses. States must meet prescribed standards and submit annual reports to the Secretary, detailing the program's nature, total guarantees provided, and the number of participating small businesses. Additionally, the Secretary must submit an annual report to specific committees, outlining the implementation of the program, the number of sureties receiving guarantees, and the states managing amounts under the program. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to a bid bond and an eligible small business concern as part of a program for small businesses. The definitions include criteria for small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals or service-disabled veterans. The curr_chunk defines small business concerns eligible for a bid bond program, including those owned by socially disadvantaged individuals, service-disabled veterans, HUBZone small businesses, and women. The term 'obligee' is also defined as the person requesting bids for performance. The curr_chunk further defines terms related to bid bonds, payment bonds, and performance bonds, including the definition of an obligee as the person requesting bids for performance. The curr_chunk defines terms related to bid bonds, payment bonds, and performance bonds, including the definitions of payment bond, performance bond, prime contractor, and principal. The curr_chunk defines terms related to bid bonds, payment bonds, and performance bonds, including the definitions of subcontractor, surety, and Secretary of Transportation. The curr_chunk defines the term 'surety' as a person or State that provides financial guarantees under bid bonds, performance bonds, and payment bonds in the event of contract breaches. The curr_chunk states that payment will be made to those supplying labor and material if the principal fails to pay, and authorizes appropriations for the Secretary for fiscal years 2010 through 2014. SEC. 3. NATIONAL INFORMATION CLEARINGHOUSE.

Amends Section 332(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code to include any Federal, State, or local mode of transportation.

SEC. 4. PROVISION OF RELEVANT INFORMATION.

Amends Section 332(d) of title 49, United States Code by striking specific entities.
